title: Why did hospitals have these frogs in their supply rooms? - Carly Anne York

multiple-choice.question: What made the African clawed frog so special in scientific research?

options.label: A
options.text: Its ability to change color and blend into its surroundings.

options.label: B
options.text: Its unique tongue that can snatch up bugs.

options.label: C
options.text: Its ability to respond to the chorionic gonadotropin hormone (hCG) in roughly 9 hours.

options.label: D
options.text: Its powerful hind claws that can tear apart larger animals.

multiple-choice.question: What was the main issue with using animals like mice and rabbits in pregnancy tests of the day?

options.label: A
options.text: They were too expensive to use.

options.label: B
options.text: They required multiple days of injections and killing and dissecting the animals.

options.label: C
options.text: They were not accurate enough.

options.label: D
options.text: They were too difficult to find.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of injecting African clawed frogs with a pituitary extract derived from an ox?

options.label: A
options.text: The frogs began to hop faster.

options.label: B
options.text: The frogs began laying eggs without the presence of a male.

options.label: C
options.text: The frogs changed color more quickly.

options.label: D
options.text: The frogs became more aggressive.

multiple-choice.question: What was the main reason why the African clawed frog is now classified as an invasive species?

options.label: A
options.text: Its ability to change color and blend into its surroundings.

options.label: B
options.text: Its ferocious appetite allowed it to outcompete native amphibians.

options.label: C
options.text: It often carries a deadly fungus called chytrid.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What has replaced the use of African clawed frogs in pregnancy tests?

options.label: A
options.text: Chemical tests that detect hCG directly.

options.label: B
options.text: Ultrasound tests.

options.label: C
options.text: Blood tests.

options.label: D
options.text: Urine tests.

title: Why is this black square famous? - Allison Leigh

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the controversial artwork that opened in St. Petersburg, Russia in 1915?

options.label: A
options.text: "The Red Square"

options.label: B
options.text: "Black Square"

options.label: C
options.text: "The Blue Painting"

options.label: D
options.text: "The White Canvas"

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what was Kazimir Malevich's creative process like when creating "Black Square"?

options.label: A
options.text: He used a very traditional and realistic approach.

options.label: B
options.text: He used a combination of different styles, including Impressionism and Cubism.

options.label: C
options.text: He used vigorous brushstrokes and incorporated fragments of hair and fingerprints into the paint.

options.label: D
options.text: He used a minimalist approach with no visible brushstrokes.

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the style that Malevich developed, which focused on non-objectivity and the use of feeling as the substance of his work?

options.label: A
options.text: Suprematism

options.label: B
options.text: Cubism

options.label: C
options.text: Futurism

options.label: D
options.text: Impressionism

multiple-choice.question: Why was Malevich's work deemed unproductive to the Communist state in the 1920s?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it was too realistic and depicted the struggles of the working class struggle.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it was too abstract and didn't fit the Socialist Realism style.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it was deemed subversive and spread anti-communist ideas.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it was too focused on individualism and didn't celebrate Soviet leaders.

multiple-choice.question: What was the symbol of Malevich's later paintings, which seemed to have abandoned Suprematism completely?

options.label: A
options.text: A red square

options.label: B
options.text: A blue square

options.label: C
options.text: A tiny black square

options.label: D
options.text: A white circle

title: What the fossil fuel industry doesn't want you to know - Al Gore

multiple-choice.question: What is the main problem with the fossil fuel industry's role in the climate crisis, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: They're not doing enough to reduce emissions.

options.label: B
options.text: They're using their lobbying power to slow down progress on climate change.

options.label: C
options.text: They're not investing enough in renewable energy.

options.label: D
options.text: They're not capturing enough emissions from their operations.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's main point about the fossil fuel industry's claims of reducing emissions through carbon capture and storage (CCS)?

options.label: A
options.text: That CCS is a viable solution to the climate crisis.

options.label: B
options.text: That CCS is not a viable solution, but it's worth continuing to research.

options.label: C
options.text: That CCS is a useful tool for reducing emissions, but it's not a substitute for phasing out fossil fuels.

options.label: D
options.text: That CCS is a form of greenwashing.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's proposal for reforming the COP process to address the influence of fossil fuel companies?

options.label: A
options.text: To give fossil fuel companies more influence over the process.

options.label: B
options.text: To exclude fossil fuel companies from the process.

options.label: C
options.text: To require companies to meet certain criteria before participating in the process.

options.label: D
options.text: To give developing countries more influence over the process.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's main point about the role of the financial system in the climate crisis?

options.label: A
options.text: That the financial system is not a significant contributor to the climate crisis.

options.label: B
options.text: That the financial system is a major obstacle to solving the climate crisis.

options.label: C
options.text: That the financial system is a neutral factor in the climate crisis.

options.label: D
options.text: That the financial system is a solution to the climate crisis.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's main point about the potential for human-caused CO2 to be removed from the atmosphere?

options.label: A
options.text: That it will take centuries for CO2 to be removed from the atmosphere.

options.label: B
options.text: That it's not possible to remove CO2 from the atmosphere.

options.label: C
options.text: That it will take decades for CO2 to be removed from the atmosphere.

options.label: D
options.text: That CO2 will continue to build up in the atmosphere even if we reach true net-zero emissions.

title: Can you change your sleep schedule?

multiple-choice.question: What determines our natural sleep schedules?

options.label: A
options.text: Our circadian system, which is anchored by a pair of nerve cell clusters located in the anterior hypothalamus.

options.label: B
options.text: Our diet and exercise routine.

options.label: C
options.text: Our social environment and lifestyle.

options.label: D
options.text: Our genetics and birth order.

multiple-choice.question: How does our circadian system manage the body's transitions between being awake and being asleep?

options.label: A
options.text: By producing hormones that induce sleep and wakefulness.

options.label: B
options.text: By regulating the body's temperature and heart rate.

options.label: C
options.text: By controlling the body's flow of hormones and managing organ functioning.

options.label: D
options.text: By influencing the body's appetite and digestion.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to our circadian system if we consistently go to sleep around 10 pm?

options.label: A
options.text: It starts producing sleep-inducing melatonin around 2 hours before then to tell our body it's time for bed.

options.label: B
options.text: It starts producing cortisol around 2 hours before then to increase our alertness.

options.label: C
options.text: It starts producing insulin around 2 hours before then to regulate our blood sugar levels.

options.label: D
options.text: It starts producing adrenaline around 2 hours before then to increase our energy levels.

multiple-choice.question: What can we do to help our circadian system accurately predict when to send out hormones?

options.label: A
options.text: Keeping consistent sleeping hours and getting sufficient contrast between bright daylight and dimmer nighttime light.

options.label: B
options.text: Eating a balanced diet and exercising regularly.

options.label: C
options.text: Reducing stress and practicing relaxation techniques.

options.label: D
options.text: Avoiding exposure to sunlight and staying in a dark room.

multiple-choice.question: What are the potential health risks of compromised circadian rhythms?

options.label: A
options.text: Metabolic disorders, vulnerable immune systems, and cardiovascular disease.

options.label: B
options.text: Cancer, diabetes, and Alzheimer's disease.

options.label: C
options.text: Obesity, depression, and anxiety disorders.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

title: Does COVID mess with your DNA?

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the study of how cells use genetic information without changing the sequence of DNA?

options.label: A
options.text: Epigenetics

options.label: B
options.text: Genomics

options.label: C
options.text: Transcription

options.label: D
options.text: Mutation

multiple-choice.question: What type of epigenetic sticky note is DNA methylation?

options.label: A
options.text: A tag that tells the cell's machinery to use a gene more often

options.label: B
options.text: A tag that tells the cell's machinery to quiet a gene down

options.label: C
options.text: A tag that tells the cell's machinery to delete a gene

options.label: D
options.text: A tag that tells the cell's machinery to rewrite a gene

options.label: A
options.text: To regulate inflammation

options.label: B
options.text: To regulate histamine signaling

options.label: C
options.text: To invade cells

options.label: D
options.text: To regulate the immune response

options.label: A
options.text: Loss of taste and smell

options.label: B
options.text: Increased heart rate

options.label: C
options.text: Increased blood pressure

options.label: D
options.text: Decreased lung function

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the potential connections between long COVID and another disease that is being studied?

options.label: A
options.text: Long COVID and chronic fatigue syndrome

options.label: B
options.text: Long COVID and diabetes

options.label: C
options.text: Long COVID and heart disease

options.label: D
options.text: Long COVID and cancer

title: What's happening to Earth's core? - Shannon Odell

multiple-choice.question: What is happening to the hydrogen atom in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: It's being absorbed by the Earth's atmosphere.

options.label: B
options.text: It's escaping from the Earth's atmosphere and joining the roughly 90 tons of material that leak out each day.

options.label: C
options.text: It's being trapped in the Earth's core.

options.label: D
options.text: It's being destroyed by the Sun's radiation.

options.label: B
options.text: It's becoming weaker.

options.label: C
options.text: It's staying the same.

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: 86 times that of carbon dioxide.

options.label: D
options.text: 10 times that of carbon dioxide.

title: Why did Megalodon go extinct? - Jack Cooper and Catalina Pimiento

multiple-choice.question: What did Danish scientist conclude about certain mysterious stones prized for their supposed medicinal powers in 1667?

options.label: A
options.text: They were fallen from the sky during lunar eclipses.

options.label: B
options.text: They were serpent tongues.

options.label: C
options.text: They were fossilized teeth belonging to a prehistoric species called megalodon.

options.label: D
options.text: They were a type of rock.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the reasons why megalodons might have stretched up to 20 meters in length?

options.label: A
options.text: Their speed in the water.

options.label: B
options.text: Their ability to navigate cold waters.

options.label: C
options.text: Their similarities with great white shark teeth.

options.label: D
options.text: Their ability to eat large prey species.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the reasons why megalodons are thought to have gone extinct around 3.5 million years ago?

options.label: A
options.text: The rise of great white sharks.

options.label: B
options.text: The cooling of the global climate and the formation of more glaciers.

options.label: C
options.text: The loss of coastal habitats due to a drop in sea level.

options.label: D
options.text: The lack of prey species in the ocean.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the reasons why the megalodon's extinction had global consequences?

options.label: A
options.text: The end of their long-distance travels disrupted nutrient transport between different ecosystems.

options.label: B
options.text: The increase in size of marine mammals after the megalodon's extinction.

options.label: C
options.text: The decrease in size of other predators after the megalodon's extinction.

options.label: D
options.text: The loss of coastal habitats due to a drop in sea level.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the reasons why conservationists are working to prevent today's sharks from facing a similar fate as the megalodon?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of their ability to navigate cold waters.

options.label: B
options.text: Because of their high energetic demands.

options.label: C
options.text: Because of the destabilizing effect of the decline of apex predators on entire ecosystems.

options.label: D
options.text: Because of their similarities with great white shark teeth.

title: 1816: The year with no summer - David Biello

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Geoengineering is a global effort, while solar radiation management is a local initiative.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The eruption of Mount Tambora

options.label: C
options.text: The eruption of Krakatoa

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.text: It is not a viable solution to climate change.
